response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not seem to capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents accurately. The fixed-policy agents consistently propose a split where the proposer gets the majority of the resources, while the decider gets a minimal amount. The flexible-policy agent, however, has proposed splits where the resources are divided more evenly or even where the decider gets more. This indicates that the previous principle does not guide the flexible-policy agent to behave like the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: When splitting resources, the proposer should receive the vast majority, leaving a minimal amount for the decider. The decider should accept this arrangement as a balance of the world.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 93 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 93 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y.
